head.title: Efficient factorization with a single pure qubit and lâ¢oâ¢gâ¢N mixed qubits

article.h1: Efficient factorization with a single pure qubit and lâ¢oâ¢gâ¢Nğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”ğ‘italic-l italic-o italic-g italic-NlogN mixed qubits

span.span: Optics Section, The Blackett Laboratory, Imperial College, London SW7 2BW, England

div.p: It is commonly assumed that Shorâ€™s quantum algorithm for the efficient factorization of a large number Nğ‘italic-NN requires a pure initial state. Here we demonstrate that a single pure qubit together with a collection of lâ¢oâ¢g2â¢Nğ‘™ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘”2ğ‘italic-l italic-o italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-Nlog_{2}N qubits in an arbitrary mixed state is sufficient to implement Shorâ€™s factorization algorithm efficiently.

The discovery of a quantum algorithm for the efficient factorization of large numbers [1] has started a rapid development of quantum information processing [2]. Following this ground-breaking result a number of experimentally realizable proposals for the implementation of quantum computers have been made, for example, in ion trap systems [3] or Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) schemes [4]. These systems are distinguished by a low decoherence rate combined with a comparatively high gate speed and therefore promise the possibility of executing many quantum gates. While noise in these systems can be made small in principle, it nevertheless imposes limitations to the maximal size of the computation [5] and to the achievable quality (e.g. the purity) of the initial state of the quantum computer. It would therefore be interesting to see whether a quantum computation necessarily requires the preparation of an initial state of high purity, or whether some parts of the quantum computer may be left in a mixed state. Such a result would be of particular interest in NMR systems in which it is difficult to prepare physically pure quantum states of nuclear spins.

The use of mixed states in quantum algorithms has had little discussion as yet. Note, however, the work of Schulman and Vazirani [7] in which they demonstrated that, starting from a set of qubits each in a thermal state, one can obtain a certain number of pure qubits using a quantum algorithm. These were then envisaged to be used for a quantum computation, while all the other qubits which are in a mixed state are discarded. If the initial states are in a thermal mixture at high temperature, the number of mixed quantum states and quantum gates required to obtain even a single pure qubit is very high. It would greatly enhance the efficiency of this approach if it would be possible to reduce the necessary number of pure qubits as much as possible at the expense of employing some of the mixed qubits in the actual quantum computation. Recently, Knill and Laflamme [6] have investigated the power of quantum computation when only a single pure qubit together with a supply of maximally mixed states is available. They were able to construct a problem that such a system can solve more efficiently than the best currently known classical algorithm.

It would be interesting to see whether these ideas can be extended to other problems of practical relevance. In this paper we demonstrate that a single pure qubit together with an initial supply of log2â¡Nsubscript2ğ‘OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N\log_{2}N qubits in an arbitrarily mixed state is sufficient to implement Shorâ€™s algorithm for the factorization of the number Nğ‘italic-NN efficiently. This is the smallest number of pure states that can achieve this task. We also demonstrate that the efficiency of the modified algorithm is essentially independent of the degree of mixing of the log2â¡Nsubscript2ğ‘OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N\log_{2}N qubits.

We proceed by outlining the problem addressed in Shorâ€™s algorithm, followed by the formulation of Shorâ€™s algorithm introduced in [8]. Then we will describe the necessary modifications to this algorithm, that will allow it to be executed using a single pure qubit and log2â¡Nsubscript2ğ‘OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N\log_{2}N qubits in a maximally mixed state.

The basis of Shorâ€™s algorithm is a classical order finding method which, recast as a quantum algorithm, can be executed in polynomial time, requiring only a polynomial amount of additional classical computation to compute the factors of Nğ‘italic-NN. The factors of a number N=pâ¢qğ‘ğ‘ğ‘italic-N RELOP:equals italic-p italic-qN=pq can, with high probability, be found if the period or order, rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr, (the lowest positive integer xâ‰ 0ğ‘¥0italic-x RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0x\neq 0 such that faâ¢(x)=1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘¥1italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:1f_{a}(x)=1 ) of the element ağ‘italic-aa in the space of the function faâ¢(x)=axâ¢modâ¢N,subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘ğ‘¥modğ‘italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ATOM:mod italic-N PUNCT:,f_{a}(x)=a^{x}\hbox{mod}\,N, is known. Then, provided ağ‘italic-aa is coprime to Nğ‘italic-NN (which can be checked classically in polynomial time using Euclidâ€™s algorithm), there is a high probability that gcdâ¢(ar2Â±1,N)gcdplus-or-minussuperscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿ21ğ‘ATOM:gcd OPEN:( italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-r ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, italic-N CLOSE:)\hbox{gcd}(a^{\frac{r}{2}}\pm 1,N) yields a factor of Nğ‘italic-NN, where gcdâ¢(Î±,Î²)gcdğ›¼ğ›½ATOM:gcd OPEN:( italic-alpha PUNCT:, italic-beta CLOSE:)\hbox{gcd}(\alpha,\beta) denotes the greatest common divisor of Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha and Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta which, again, can be determined efficiently using Euclidâ€™s algorithm [1].

We begin by examining the formulation of Shorâ€™s algorithm as given in [8] and use it as a basis to demonstrate the main result of this paper. First of all we introduce the transformation Uaâ¢|xâŸ©=|aâ¢xâ¢modâ¢NâŸ©subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ketğ‘¥ketğ‘ğ‘¥modğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-x CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals VERTBAR:| italic-a italic-x ATOM:mod italic-N CLOSE:rangleU_{a}\left|x\right\rangle=\left|ax\,\hbox{mod}\,N\right\rangle where x=0,â‹¯,N-1.ğ‘¥0â‹¯ğ‘1italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 PERIOD:.x=0,\cdots,N-1. Provided ağ‘italic-aa is coprime to Nğ‘italic-NN this is a unitary transformation and has eigenvectors

div.p: â€™kickingâ€™ the â€™globalâ€™ phase shift acquired on the second qubit into a relative phase in the first qubit. We can now perform measurements on the first qubit which will allow us to estimate rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr, however, we cannot create the eigenstates of Uasubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{a} without knowledge of rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr. Instead one can use the fact [8] that âˆ‘j=0r-1|ÏˆjâŸ©=|1âŸ©subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘—0ketsubscriptğœ“ğ‘—ket1SUMOP:sum POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-r ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals VERTBAR:| NUMBER:1 CLOSE:rangle\sum^{r-1}_{j=0}\left|\psi_{j}\right\rangle=\left|1\right\rangle and conditionally apply Uasubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{a} to the state |1âŸ©ket1VERTBAR:| NUMBER:1 CLOSE:rangle\left|1\right\rangle (which obviously requires no knowledge of rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr) in the second qubit

div.p: This state is, of course, entangled, so when we make measurements on the first qubit we will get an estimate of e2â¢Ï€â¢iâ¢jrsuperscriptğ‘’2ğœ‹ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘Ÿitalic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-i italic-j ARG:end ARG:start italic-r ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ende^{\frac{2\pi ij}{r}}, with jğ‘—italic-jj (which corresponds to an eigenstate) selected at random.

How do we estimate this phase and the value of rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr accurately? The network in Fig. 1 will give us, with a sufficient probability, the best Lğ¿italic-LL-bit estimate of the value of 2Lâ¢j/rsuperscript2ğ¿ğ‘—ğ‘ŸNUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-j MULOP:divide italic-r2^{L}j/r [8].

qubits. The remaining operations on the control qubits realise the quantum inverse Fourier transform. A measurement on each of these qubits produces a binary number c=âˆ‘i=0L-12iâ¢miğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–0ğ¿1superscript2ğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘–italic-c RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endc=\sum_{i=0}^{L-1}2^{i}m_{i} such that with a finite probability c/2Lğ‘superscript2ğ¿italic-c MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endc/2^{L} is the best estimate of j/rğ‘—ğ‘Ÿitalic-j MULOP:divide italic-rj/r for some integer jğ‘—italic-jj again selected at random on measurement.

The first modification to this algorithm comes when we notice that the gates within the Fourier transform are applied sequentially on the qubits. Thus instead of performing the entire transform and then making measurements on all control qubits afterwards we may apply the single qubit (Hadamard) operation to the first qubit and then measure it. The operations (controlled phase shifts) controlled by this first qubit are then replaced by single qubit operations given the result of the measurement on the first. This â€™semi-classicalâ€™ modification [10] preserves the probabilities of all measurement results.

Taking this further we need only insist on one control qubit and the remaining âŒˆlog2â¡NâŒ‰subscript2ğ‘OPEN:lceil OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N CLOSE:rceil\lceil\log_{2}{N}\rceil qubits as we can â€™recycleâ€™ the control qubit after each measurement (Fig. 2): we perform all the necessary operations of the first control qubit including measurements, followed by all the operations of the second control qubit on the same physical qubit system given the results of previous measurements, and so on [11].

We can, therefore, already implement Shorâ€™s algorithm with 1+âŒˆlog2â¡NâŒ‰1subscript2ğ‘NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus OPEN:lceil OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N CLOSE:rceil1+\lceil\log_{2}{N}\rceil pure qubits that is, one control qubit and âŒˆlog2â¡NâŒ‰subscript2ğ‘OPEN:lceil OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N CLOSE:rceil\lceil\log_{2}{N}\rceil of the remaining qubits. We will find later that we can also replace the âŒˆlog2â¡NâŒ‰subscript2ğ‘OPEN:lceil OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N CLOSE:rceil\lceil\log_{2}{N}\rceil pure qubits with âŒˆlog2â¡NâŒ‰subscript2ğ‘OPEN:lceil OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N CLOSE:rceil\lceil\log_{2}{N}\rceil maximally mixed qubits and find the order rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr efficiently (see also [12]). To see why this is the case we first need to examine the unitary transformation Uasubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{a} more closely.

The unitarity of the transform together with the fact that it maps a â€™numberâ€™ state |xâŸ©ketğ‘¥VERTBAR:| italic-x CLOSE:rangle\left|x\right\rangle to a â€™numberâ€™ state |aâ¢xâ¢modâ¢NâŸ©ketğ‘ğ‘¥modğ‘VERTBAR:| italic-a italic-x ATOM:mod italic-N CLOSE:rangle\left|ax\,\hbox{mod}\,N\right\rangle means that on repeated application of Uasubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{a} periodic sequences are induced on all the numbers x=0,1,â‹¯,N-1ğ‘¥01â‹¯ğ‘1italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1x=0,1,\cdots,N-1, that is, there is an Râ¢(x)ğ‘…ğ‘¥italic-R OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)R(x) such that UaRâ¢(x)â¢|xâŸ©=|xâŸ©superscriptsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘¥ketğ‘¥ketğ‘¥italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-R OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-x CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals VERTBAR:| italic-x CLOSE:rangleU_{a}^{R(x)}\left|x\right\rangle=\left|x\right\rangle. div.p: It is the first of these sequences (with g=1ğ‘”1italic-g RELOP:equals NUMBER:1g=1) whose number of members is what we previously called the â€™orderâ€™, rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr, of ağ‘italic-aa modulo Nğ‘italic-NN and it is this period that we need to find to factorize Nğ‘italic-NN. However, there is a relationship between the order of the sequence with g=1ğ‘”1italic-g RELOP:equals NUMBER:1g=1 and the orders of all the other sequences with gâ‰ 1ğ‘”1italic-g RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:1g\neq 1. We will label each of the different sequences by dğ‘‘italic-dd and the number of members in each sequence by rdsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{d}. Uasubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{a} obeys the condition Uar=Isuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ¼italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-IU_{a}^{r}=I so it is clear that rd|rconditionalsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿitalic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-rr_{d}|r, that is, the orders of all the sequences divides that of the sequence with g=1ğ‘”1italic-g RELOP:equals NUMBER:1g=1. In fact we will find that nearly all of the numbers 0,1,â‹¯,N-101â‹¯ğ‘1NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:10,1,\cdots,N-1 are contained within a sequence that has the same order as the first sequence. We can find a lower bound on the probability that for a number gâˆˆ0,1,â‹¯,N-1ğ‘”01â‹¯ğ‘1italic-g RELOP:element-of NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1g\in 0,1,\cdots,N-1 the state |gâ¢axâ¢modâ¢NâŸ©ketğ‘”superscriptğ‘ğ‘¥modğ‘VERTBAR:| italic-g italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ATOM:mod italic-N CLOSE:rangle|ga^{x}\hbox{mod}N\rangle is contained within a sequence of order rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr.

p.span: Given two prime numbers pğ‘italic-pp and qğ‘italic-qq we define r as the lowest positive integer x such that ax-1â‰¡0â¢ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘‘â¢(pâ¢q)superscriptğ‘ğ‘¥10ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:0 ATOM:italic-mod OPEN:( italic-p italic-q CLOSE:)a^{x}-1\equiv 0\,\hbox{mod}\,(pq) for an arbitrary integer ağ‘italic-aa. Then gâ¢ax-gâ‰¡0â¢ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘‘â¢(pâ¢q)ğ‘”superscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘”0ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘italic-g italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-g RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:0 ATOM:italic-mod OPEN:( italic-p italic-q CLOSE:)ga^{x}-g\equiv 0\,\hbox{mod}\,(pq) with x<rğ‘¥ğ‘Ÿitalic-x RELOP:less-than italic-rx<r for at most p+q-1ğ‘ğ‘1italic-p ADDOP:plus italic-q ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1p+q-1 values of gğ‘”italic-gg in the interval 0â‰¤aâ‰¤pâ¢q-10ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘1NUMBER:0 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-a RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-p italic-q ADDOP:minus NUMBER:10\leq a\leq pq-1.

div.p: We can now see that the probability, Prsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿitalic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP_{r}, of picking gğ‘”italic-gg at random such that the lowest xğ‘¥italic-xx for which gâ¢axâ‰¡gâ¢modâ¢(pâ¢q)ğ‘”superscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘”modğ‘ğ‘italic-g italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-g ATOM:mod OPEN:( italic-p italic-q CLOSE:)ga^{x}\equiv g\,\hbox{mod}\,(pq) is rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr, is Prâ‰¥(pâ¢q-(p+q-1))/pâ¢q=(p-1)â¢(q-1)/pâ¢qsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘1ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘1ğ‘1ğ‘ğ‘italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-equals OPEN:( italic-p italic-q ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-p ADDOP:plus italic-q ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-p italic-q RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-p ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-q ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-p italic-qP_{r}\geq(pq-(p+q-1))/pq=(p-1)(q-1)/pq which approaches unity as pğ‘italic-pp and qğ‘italic-qq become large.
This tells us that if we set up an algorithm that actually finds the order of a random sequence we still have a good chance that this order is in fact rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr.

The rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr eigenstates of Uasubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{a} in equation 1 are orthogonal superpositions of the members of the sequence with g=1ğ‘”1italic-g RELOP:equals NUMBER:1g=1. In exactly the same way we can form the remaining N-rğ‘ğ‘Ÿitalic-N ADDOP:minus italic-rN-r eigenstates of Uasubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{a} as orthogonal superpositions of members of each of the other sequences. We write these as

semantics.annotation: VERTBAR:| italic-psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-i italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-k ARG:end ARG:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ATOM:mod italic-N CLOSE:rangle

div.p: where dğ‘‘italic-dd labels the sequence and jd=0,â‹¯,rd-1subscriptğ‘—ğ‘‘0â‹¯subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘1italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1j_{d}=0,\cdots,r_{d}-1 the eigenstates of Uasubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{a} within the sequence dğ‘‘italic-dd. |gdâŸ©ketsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘‘VERTBAR:| italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|g_{d}\right\rangle is the lowest member of the dğ‘‘italic-ddth sequence. Each eigenstate has corresponding eigenvalue e2â¢Ï€â¢iâ¢jd/rdsuperscriptğ‘’2ğœ‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘—ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-i italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ende^{2\pi ij_{d}/r_{d}} so using the same phase estimation techniques allows us to estimate jd/rdsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:endj_{d}/r_{d} given the state |ÏˆjddâŸ©ketsubscriptsuperscriptğœ“ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘—ğ‘‘VERTBAR:| italic-psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|\psi^{d}_{j_{d}}\right\rangle. Again, this requires knowledge of the sequences induced by Uasubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{a} so instead we may perform the phase estimation technique on the maximally mixed state

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:bold-1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-N ARG:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-N ARG:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-k CLOSE:rangle OPEN:langle italic-k VERTBAR:| RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-N ARG:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle OPEN:langle italic-psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| PERIOD:.

div.p: Phase estimation now estimates the value of jd/rdsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:endj_{d}/r_{d} for jdsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘‘italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:endj_{d} and dğ‘‘italic-dd chosen at random but as we have seen above nearly all the orders rdsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{d} are equal to rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr.

Note that in Shorâ€™s original algorithm the âŒˆlog2â¡NâŒ‰subscript2ğ‘OPEN:lceil OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N CLOSE:rceil\lceil\log_{2}{N}\rceil qubits encode a phase change into the control qubits which is quantum mechanically correlated to eigenstates of Uasubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{a} our modification encodes a phase change which is classically correlated to the eigenstates. This includes not only the group of eigenstates consisting of superpositions of elements in the first sequence (see Eq. Efficient factorization with a single pure qubit and lâ¢oâ¢gâ¢Nğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”ğ‘italic-l italic-o italic-g italic-NlogN mixed qubits) but groups of eigenstates consisting of superpositions of elements in each of the other sequences. However by theorem 1 most of these sequences have the same order and will encode the value rd=rsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿitalic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-rr_{d}=r into the control qubits. This makes it intuitively clear that the algorithm is still efficient. Note however that although the âŒˆlog2â¡NâŒ‰subscript2ğ‘OPEN:lceil OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N CLOSE:rceil\lceil\log_{2}{N}\rceil mixed qubits are only classically correlated to the pure qubit, entanglement still exists in the system: one can partition the system into two halves one containing some mixed qubits and the other containing the remaining mixed qubits and the pure qubit. Then it can be checked, that this bipartite system can have negative partial transpose and is therefore entangled [13].

In the following we will prove strictly that this modified version of Shorâ€™s algorithm is indeed still efficient for order finding. Shorâ€™s algorithm requires Oâ¢(logâ¡logâ¡r)ğ‘‚ğ‘Ÿitalic-O OPEN:( OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-r CLOSE:)O\left(\log\log r\right) repetitions for it to have a high chance of finding the order whereas the mixed state Shorâ€™s algorithm uses exactly the same resources as Shorâ€™s original algorithm but requires

semantics.annotation: italic-O OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-p italic-q ARG:end ARG:start OPEN:( italic-p ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-q ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) ARG:end OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-r CLOSE:)

div.p: repetitions for it to have a high chance of finding the order which, in the limit p,qâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘ğ‘italic-p PUNCT:, italic-q ARROW:rightarrow ID:infinityp,q\rightarrow\infty, is equally as efficient as Shorâ€™s algorithm. For simplicity we will prove this efficiency result for a mixed state algorithm with Lğ¿italic-LL control qubits. For the reasons outlined above the result will be identical using a single pure control qubit. The proof follows very closely that of Shor [1].

Pick an Lğ¿italic-LL such the N2<t=2L<2â¢N2superscriptğ‘2ğ‘¡superscript2ğ¿2superscriptğ‘2italic-N POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:2 italic-N POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN^{2}<t=2^{L}<2N^{2}. The initial state of our system with all the control qubits grouped into the first state is

div.p: Application of the controlled Ua,Ua2,â‹¯,Ua2L-1subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘2â‹¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘superscript2ğ¿1italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:cdots PUNCT:, italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-L ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endU_{a},U_{a}^{2},\cdots,U_{a}^{2^{L-1}} gates and the inverse Fourier transform yields the state

italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-i italic-b OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-l ARG:end ARG:start italic-t ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-k CLOSE:rangle OPEN:langle italic-l VERTBAR:| MULOP:tensor-product VERTBAR:| italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle OPEN:langle italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| PERIOD:.

div.p: We now make a measurement on the first state. The probability that the result cğ‘italic-cc is obtained is

div.p: Sğ‘†italic-SS is just an arithmetic progression and |S|2superscriptğ‘†2VERTBAR:| italic-S VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end|S|^{2} can easily be bounded by

div.p: Because t>N2ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘2italic-t RELOP:greater-than italic-N POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endt>N^{2} this is a sufficient condition that given c/tğ‘ğ‘¡italic-c MULOP:divide italic-tc/t there is only one fraction jd/rdsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:endj_{d}/r_{d} with rd<Nsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘ğ‘italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-Nr_{d}<N such that the above condition is obeyed. For a given measurement result cğ‘italic-cc there are at least (p-1)â¢(q-1)/rğ‘1ğ‘1ğ‘ŸOPEN:( italic-p ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-q ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-r(p-1)(q-1)/r corresponding values of rdsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{d} with rd=rsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿitalic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-rr_{d}=r by theorem 1. So the probability that c/tğ‘ğ‘¡italic-c MULOP:divide italic-tc/t is the best estimate of a fraction with denominator rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr is

semantics.annotation: italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-c CLOSE:) RELOP:greater-than FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-N italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-S VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:4 OPEN:( italic-p ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-q ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-N italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-r ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: We now require that the numerator, jdsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘‘italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:endj_{d}, is coprime to rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr otherwise cancellation of common factors will occur in jd/rsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿitalic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-rj_{d}/r. There are Ï•â¢(r)italic-Ï•ğ‘Ÿitalic-phi OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:)\phi(r) values of jdsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘‘italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:endj_{d} which are less than and coprime to rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr, where Ï•italic-Ï•italic-phi\phi is Eulerâ€™s totient function [9]. Thus the probability that we can calculate rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr is P>4â¢(p-1)â¢(q-1)â¢Ï•â¢(r)/Nâ¢râ¢Ï€2.ğ‘ƒ4ğ‘1ğ‘1italic-Ï•ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğœ‹2italic-P RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:4 OPEN:( italic-p ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-q ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) italic-phi OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-N italic-r italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.P>4(p-1)(q-1)\phi(r)/Nr\pi^{2}. Using a theorem by Hardy and Wright (theorem 328) [9] that Ï•â¢(r)/r>Î´/logâ¡logâ¡ritalic-Ï•ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ›¿ğ‘Ÿitalic-phi OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-r RELOP:greater-than italic-delta MULOP:divide OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-r\phi(r)/r>\delta/\log\log r for some constant Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta we find that the number of times that we need run the algorithm to have a high chance of finding the period, rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr â–¡â–¡FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start Box FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{\Box}is given by Eq. (8).

We have thus found that one pure qubit and a supply of maximally mixed qubits is sufficient to implement Shorâ€™s algorithm, requiring no more resources in terms of quantum operations or physical systems than the algorithm operating on pure quantum states. This implies that the algorithm presented here is a â€™trueâ€™ quantum algorithm, achieving an exponential speedup using only polynomial resources. This may be suprising as the degree of mixing of the state of the computer is high. However, the mixing decrease as the algorithm proceeds but never below a mixture of N/rdğ‘subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘italic-N MULOP:divide italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN/r_{d} eigenstates where rdsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{d} is the measured period. Furthermore, it should be noted that despite this strong degree of mixing the quantum computer actually evolves into an entangled state. It is this entanglement that appears to be responsible for the computational speedup.

Maximally mixed states are intuitively a less â€™costlyâ€™ resource than pure states but, in fact, we do not need to require maximally mixed states: we could equally well use any random state (mixed or pure) on which to perform the controlled Uasubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{a} operations. The average efficiency over all these states would then be as we have shown in this paper. In particular thermal states of nuclear spins (e.g. in NMR), where the occupation of the ground state is only slightly greater than that of the first excited state, would change the efficiency of this algorithm by only a small amount leaving it an efficient algorithm. This ability of highly mixed states to support efficient quantum computation points towards the possibility of the implementation of true quantum computation for example in NMR systems.

The authors would like to thank Kevin Buzzard for valuable advice on number theory and S. Bose, R. Jozsa, R. Laflamme, M. Nielsen and C. Zalka for helpful comments. This work is supported by the EPSRC, the Leverhulme Trust, and the EU project EQUIP.
